data.title: RUTH GORDON, THE ACTRESS, DIES AT 88
data.text:
Ruth Gordon, an actress and writer whose perpetual energies seemed to defy time, died yesterday at her summer home in Edgartown, Mass. She was 88 years old.

In those years - the last 70 of them in and around the worlds of stage, screen, television and letters - Miss Gordon manifested a fearsome will and an insatiable appetite for things new. She was a seaman's daughter, and she never tired of exploration or conquest.

''Pan me, don't give me the part, publish everybody's book but this one and I will still make it!'' Miss Gordon wrote in ''My Side,'' her autobiography. ''Why? Because I believe I will. If you believe, then you hang on. If you believe, it means you've got imagination, you don't need stuff thrown out for you in a blueprint, you don't face facts - what can stop you? If I don't make it today, I'll come in tomorrow.''

Garson Kanin, Miss Gordon's husband of 43 years, said that even her last day of life was typically full, with walks, talks, errands and a morning of work on a new play. She made her last public appearance only two weeks ago - at a benefit showing of the film ''Harold and Maude'' - and she had recently finished acting in four films. In one of them, characteristically enough, Miss Gordon insisted on doing her own motorcycle stunts.
